ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PEDESTRIAN CROSSING AT 7 1/2 M.S. UPPER SERANGOON ROAD


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether and when a Pedestrian Crossing will be established at the 7 1/2 milestone, Upper Serangoon Road.

    The Minister of State for the Prime Minister's Department (Inche Yaacob bin Mohamed Al-Haj) (for the Deputy Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, under present circumstances my Ministry has no intention to establish a pedestrian crossing at 7½ milestone, Upper Serangoon Road. The locality around is not heavily populated. The residential area here is widely spread. There are three schools in the

Column: 624

locality with school signs to warn motorists, and each school has a traffic warden to assist school children to cross the road during peak hours. Although traffic is quite heavy in the morning and the afternoon, it is not so throughout the day and people can safely cross the road.

POLICE STATION IN PUNGGOL CONSTITUENCY


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister of Defence whether and when a Police Station will be built in the Punggol Constituency.

    The Minister of State of Defence (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no immediate plans for a police station in the Punggol Constituency which is serviced by the Paya Lebar Police Station. However, a site for a police post at 9 m.s. Punggol Road close to the Government Health Clinic has been obtained and it is expected this post will be in operation by mid-1966.

    The Chairman: We are now on Head 0702 - Hospitals Division. Amendment No. (1) standing in the name of Mr Teong Eng Siong.

    Head 0702 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0702 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1051.

    Mr Speaker, in the field of medical services, our country has won general acclaim. The Government has spent $40 million to look after the health and medical services for the people. Clinics have been built to look after the people's health. In spite of the smallness of our country, our health services can be said

Column: 625

to be on par with the standard obtainable in any other country. For this, I have to thank the Minister for Health and our Government for their able leadership. But there is nothing perfect in all respects. Therefore, I have to comment somewhat on the drawbacks and shortcomings of the General Hospital.

    The General Hospital has been set up for quite a long time. It has an important place in Singapore's medical history. It has set up an exemplary record in medical service. Nevertheless, I have received several complaints from members of the public about the General Hospital. Firstly, I would like to give an example. In my constituency, there is a spinster 60 years old who cannot see beyond several yards. She went for treatment at the General Hospital. But the officer-in-charge of the Eye Clinic there did not treat her eye disease and did not give any reasons. So this lady was very frustrated and came to see me. I sent her with a letter to see the Medical Officer-in-charge on the 6th of December. He recorded her particulars, including her name and address, and asked her to go back, telling her that she would be called when necessary. As far as I understand, the lady, after three weeks, has not been called back for any attention. Sir, I would like the Minister concerned to see whether there is such an incident, and I would like to know what is the reason for this happening.

    Secondly, in respect of doctors and nurses, they do not promptly deal with emergency cases. Of course, I understand there are lots of sick people going to the General Hospital to seek treatment, and I understand the doctors and nurses are overworked. But in emergency or acute cases, doctors and nurses seem not to have acted promptly in dealing with them. Sometimes patients suffering from appendicitis have had to wait for two or three hours, and this delay might have been fatal to them. So I urge the hospital authorities to be more concerned with these emergency cases and act promptly when they arise.

    Thirdly, concerning the attitude of some nurses in the General Hospital.

Column: 626

Many members of the public have complained that the nurses have not been courteous enough when dealing with patients. Sometimes they have been contemptuous. So I hope the authorities concerned will look into this matter. I hope such incidents have been very rare, and that there will not be any more of these to destroy the good reputation of our medical institutions. The staff should be taught courtesy and to be kind and tender-hearted especially when dealing with patients.

    Mr Speaker, I understand the Ministry of Health has been conducting a nurse-training course. Apart from giving nurses medical training, they should also be given courtesy training so that they may treat members of the public well, especially the patients.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the Member for Sembawang has three sets of complaints to make against the Ministry of Health. I would like to take them in the order in which they have been presented.

    The first complaint, in one particular case, is that there was a 60-year old woman who had an eye complaint and who did not receive any attention when she went to the Opthalmic Department of the General Hospital; and when the complainant saw the Member for Sembawang about this, he gave her a letter of introduction which was duly considered by the people in charge, taken note of, and she was asked to go back and she would be told when to appear again at the hospital. But up till now - it is three weeks since he wrote the letter of introduction - there has been no news requesting her to turn up at the hospital for attention. I want to say that I myself do get similar requests for letters of introduction to see this doctor or that surgeon and I have to tell them that although I personally may be the Minister for Health, I am not a Doctor of Medicine and I am not in a position to give any letters of introduction. So I think my good friend the Member for Sembawang has taken upon himself quite a lot by issuing letters of introduction addressed to the doctors in the

Column: 627

hospital. The proper procedure would be to advise the patient, or whoever is not feeling too well, to first see a doctor, who would then be in a position to diagnose the complaint.

2.45 p.m.

    After examining the condition of the patient, this particular doctor would then give a letter - what is known as a letter of referral; that is to say, a general practitioner refers a patient to a specialist, who would then attend on him. So I hope in future instances, my hon. friend from Sembawang would do better to follow this line of routine rather than issue letters of introduction addressed to various officials of my Ministry. However, if he will be good enough to let me know the name of this particular patient, the 60-year old woman, I will try to assist him in this respect, to make sure that she gets some attention, but this does not go for all other cases in future.

    His second complaint is that many patients in the General Hospital have to wait a long time before receiving attention. I am afraid he is not so particular in this complaint in that he makes a very general statement. It is very difficult to try to follow it up, and I would prefer if he could give me specific instances of so-called delays encountered by patients before they received attention. I must, however, state that it is more than one and a half years ago, since August 1964, that the Outpatient Dispensary of the General Hospital was closed down. In its place, there is a 24-hour Emergency Unit in the General Hospital to deal with serious emergencies or with cases where people have been involved in motor accidents. Ever since that time, I have been given to understand that all such cases have been promptly look after, and many of those who have had occasion to go to this emergency unit have indicated how pleased they were that the reorganisation has now given them more efficient and quicker service than was available hitherto.

    If it is the case of an emergency patient having to wait for a long time for a doctor to examine his case, I would appreciate it if the Member for Sembawang would indicate the patient concerned and the day on which this incident happened, so that I can then follow it up, rather than making just a complaint that people have to wait for a long time to see a doctor and just stopping there. I am afraid I am not in a position to follow up on a general complaint of that nature.

    As for the third complaint about the attitude of some nurses - I am glad that he says some nurses but not all nurses - who may appear to be somewhat ill-mannered and show a lack of patience with some of those who are ill, I think it is almost impossible to expect a hundred per cent of all nurses to be very well-mannered and full of patience all the time. Here again I do not think it would be fair to make just a general statement without giving specific instances of bad, ill-mannered treatment of patients in hospitals. It is almost impossible to defend against such a complaint. But in regard to the remarks of the Member that perhaps in the School of Nursing there should be established a courtesy course, I believe this is a matter which the hon. Member for Moulmein has already raised some time ago, namely, that perhaps we should institute a courtesy course for our nurses. This is part and parcel of the general training of nurses, and I do not think it is necessary to have a specific courtesy course for nurses in general. They are expected to treat everyone with courtesy, more so towards those who are ill and who would really need not only their attention but also normal courtesy which one citizen would extend to another.

    I hope I have been able to answer all the three points raised by the hon. Member for Sembawang. Should he have occasion to have complaints, I would appreciate it if he could direct them to me personally, giving more information than he has given.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, assistant nursing is a profession which requires the necessary education, training and skill. Quite a number of our girls who have qualifications higher than the minimum necessary for assistant nurses prefer to go for other jobs rather than apply as assistant nurses. The reason is that they have to undergo training for not less than two years, and they have to pass an examination. Once they are accepted into the medical service, they have to go on shift duties. There are times when they have to be awake the whole night until morning. There are times when they have to work while others have their day off on

Column: 630

public holidays. However that may be, there is a sufficient number of our girls who wish to work in the hospitals in order to give assistance to members of the public who require medical attention, by joining the service as assistant nurses. The spirit of these girls who do want to join as assistant nurses is dampened by the existence of the new government system - this applies to pupil assistant nurses - whereby those who passed their examination after their training have to reapply in order to become assistant nurses and serve in the hospitals. Those who are selected will continue to serve as assistant nurses and those who are not selected will be victimised. They cannot work in private clinics because they have qualifications only as assistant nurses, and private clinics do not employ assistant nurses. I do not know whether there are nurses and midwives who, after having passed their examination, are required to reapply. If the conditions of employing the nurses and midwives are the same as assistant nurses, and those who are not selected can work in private clinics, and so also the midwives can work in private clinics, or become private certified midwives, then their time and training would not have been wasted. These assistant nurses cannot work as private assistant nurses. The only place where they can work is in the hospital. Therefore, I hope the Minister concerned will see to it that the system whereby assistant nurses have to reapply in order that they can be taken on as assistant nurses will be abolished. This will enable those who have passed their examination to work straightaway as assistant nurses, because they have had training for not less than two years. Otherwise they will merely be victims of circumstances, and it would not be possible for them to earn their living by working elsewhere in a private capacity. Two years of their time would thus have been wasted. I hope the Minister for Health will see to it that the assistant nurses who have passed their examination will be accepted rightaway to serve as assistant nurses in the hospitals.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member for Kampong Kembangan is raising the question of some assistant nurses who are now in the Tan Tock Seng Hospital over their recruitment policy, which has shown a slight change as compared with previous years. There is no question at all regarding the value of assistant nurses in our hospital service. When opening the School for Assistant Nurses in Thomson Road Hospital some months back, I had occasion to pay tribute to the assistant nursing service which has become one of the pillars of our hospital service in assisting staff nurses to run our hospitals. There is a shortage of trained nurses as well as trained assistant nurses in our hospitals, and this will be so for quite some time.

3.00 p.m.

    But unfortunately, owing to the fact that a number of approved posts in the hospitals for assistant nurses would appear to be a little less than the number of pupils in the School of Nursing, it was necessary in the middle of this year (that is to say, in July), for a tripartite discussion to be held between the Public Service Commission, the Treasury, and the Ministry of Health, to ensure that by next year, 1966-7, a situation will not arise where there are less posts than there are numbers of trained assistant nurses who have graduated; in other words, we will be having trained assistant nurses and not having posts for them. Therefore, it has been decided that the few batches of assistant nurses that will graduate this year will be informed that it would be necessary for them to go through a selection exercise by the Public Service Commission. It was not necessary to do so in the past because there were more approved posts than there were trained assistant nurses. So it was actually a case of the Public Service Commission having waived the requirements of a selection exercise after graduation. Hence, there was a little unhappiness amongst assistant nurses in

Column: 632

Tan Tock Seng Hospital, that there has been a change in the terms of service. So I would like to assure those who have graduated this year from the School of Nursing as assistant nurses, that there should be no difficulty in placing them on the permanent establishment, but this is a precautionary measure being taken by the officials so as not to have a situation whereby they find themselves caught, as it were, with more trained nurses than there are established posts approved by Treasury.

    Next, I would like to say that the question of nurses in our hospital service is a matter that is receiving attention by the Nursing Board. This is a question of reviewing the whole position of staffing of nurses in our hospitals. A memorandum is already in preparation and it will be studied by the Ministry during the course of the next few months. It is hoped that when this matter is finally considered, a situation like that which has recently taken place in Tan Tock Seng Hospital will not have to take place at all.

But I would ask him what is the position regarding assistant nurses who graduate in the years to come?

Certain wards in certain hospitals have T.V. sets installed through the kindness and excellent social spirit of either certain individuals or charitable organisations. I hope this spirit can be continued and also that the Member for Aljunied would make a move by donating one T.V. set so that others may follow! Otherwise I may have to work very hard with our Hon. Minister for Finance to get him to grant more money. We would like to grant all available services, but it is a question of economy and finance. Since an excellent example

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, this provision is for the reimbursement of a number of leper patients who were originally from Singapore but later were sent to the Malaysian leper settlements of Sungei Buloh and Pulau Jerejak. There are places available in our leper settlement known as Trafalgar Home. In fact, unlike other hospitals, we are in the fortunate position of having accommodation for more than a thousand patients suffering from leprosy, but at the moment there are less than 600 patients receiving attention.

    At the moment the number in Sungei Buloh is around 24. Leprosy is a condition which could take a number of years to cure, so that many of the patients are practically permanently settled down there. It would be quite a difficult matter to bring them back to Singapore, although we could handle the situation if they were here. So it is probably better to allow them to continue settling

    Sir, I do not know whether the Hon. the Member for Health is aware of the mosquito nuisance that is rampant, I believe, not only in my constituency but also in others as well. I do not know whether strong measures have been taken to eradicate such nuisance. Almost every night, for myself, I have got to get up several times to beat off these mosquitoes.

    The other fact is the question of flies. It seems to me that this nuisance is also on the increase. I wish to know from the Hon. Minister for Health what measures his Ministry will take to eradicate such nuisances in respect of mosquitoes and flies.

3.30 p.m.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, regarding these two complaints, the fly and the mosquito nuisances, I think it is not a question of my Ministry not being aware of their existence so much as what steps are to be taken to put a stop to them, and these have been unfortunately allowed to deteriorate for quite some years.

    As indicated previously in this debate, in the Appendix to His Excellency's Speech, an indication was given that for the coming year, there will be a reorganisation of the Environmental health services which will include Public Cleansing, Hawkers and the Anti-mosquito services. The mosquito nuisance is somewhat correlated to a number of other factors besides just dealing with mosquitoes by our so-called Anti-Malarial Department. If public cleansing is defective - and unfortunately it is to a great extent - this will bring about considerable piles of refuse not being taken away and dealt with, and such refuse will block drains and, therefore, there will be stagnant water which will ultimately bring about mosquito-breeding and hence the numerous hordes of mosquitoes which worry not only the Member for Punggol but also many residents on this island.

    I have already indicated that there will be licensing of the 40,000 to 50,000 hawkers during the coming year, and that will be the first step in the control of hawkers which will, of course, affect the reorganisation of the public cleansing services. And when this is tackled, it will somewhat reduce the mosquito nuisance, because we will then be able to clear away stagnant pools of water now collecting in numerous drains throughout the city.

    But I would like to deal with the mosquito nuisance particularly, as the tendency up to the present for the last 40 to 50 years has been to tackle the mosquito problem as an anti-malarial measure, which is correct, because as far back as 50 years ago - 1910 to be

Column: 637

exact - there used to be tens of thousands of malarial cases with over 2,000 deaths each year from malaria. And then an Anti-Mosquito Ordinance was passed which brought about concerted action against the anopheles mosquito which was responsible for malaria. Over a period of years, malaria became controlled in Singapore and the cases of malaria began to drop considerably. But during the Japanese occupation - the years 1941-1945 - the anti-malarial measures collapsed and again by 1945, we came back to the 1910 situation where over 2,000 people died from malaria. Steps were again taken to put our anti-malarial measures back to their original footing, and it was only in 1952 that we went back to the pre-war control of malaria. So all this while, we have had more or less been concentrating on anti-malarial measures. They have been fairly effective, but unfortunately, with the considerable urban development within the city area and less attention being paid to the construction of subsoil drainage and open drains for the carriage of drainage water, we are beginning to have the mosquito nuisance because of the collection of stagnant pools of water. And I am afraid also that since May 1963 there have been some difficulties with the workers in the Anti-Malarial Department who refuse to cut grass if they are oilers. They insist on division of labour. For example, an anti-malarial oiler who distributes oil over surfaces of water in the past used to cut grass every sixth day, but unfortunately they now say that they want something extra for cutting grass, and there has been some difficulty in agreeing to this request of division of labour. So for the forthcoming year there will be a re-organisation to put this matter right. Also mosquitoes are no longer a nuisance when they just bite people, because we are beginning to find that the so-called mosquito nuisance is no longer a nuisance. There are a number of other types of diseases appearing, like filariasis, more commonly known as elephantiasis, caused by mosquitoes biting individuals and there is encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) and

Column: 638

hemorrhagic fever (that is bleeding into the skin and organs) - all caused as a result of mosquito bites. We are getting something like a hundred cases per year. So because of these new trends arising out of mosquito bites, it has been decided to make malaria what is known as a notifiable disease, that is to say, if a person has malaria, which is confirmed by taking a blood slide, it becomes obligatory of the doctor to notify the Ministry of Health. We shall be bringing out a new Bill to be called the Destruction of Mosquito Act so that we will be able to have the legislative authority to deal rather strongly with people who are breeding mosquitoes probably very innocently in their gardens by putting out shanghai jars for collecting rainwater for their gardens, but at the same time for breeding mosquitoes, and they may all the time be complaining why there are mosquitoes in their houses when they are themselves helping mosquitoes to breed. There will also be created a new Anti-Mosquito Control Unit. As I have said, in the past, the tendency has always been on anti-malarial work - but now we shall call it the Anti-Mosquito Control Unit - to cover anti-malaria and other diseases caused by mosquitoes. We have been fairly successful in controlling the T.B. problems by establishing an Anti-T.B. Control Unit. So we intend very soon to establish what is known as the Anti-Mosquito Control Unit to co-ordinate the activities of the Anti-Mosquito Department, and to cover the whole island. We hope that within a few years the so-called mosquito nuisance will be gradually reduced and Singapore will be mosquito-free as far as possible. We can say that Singapore has been free of malaria for a number of years, but we are really right in the heart of a very malarious region, which includes Indonesia and our next-door neighbour, Malaysia. Every year we have a few hundred cases of malaria recorded in Singapore but they are all cases that are imported into Singapore and none indigenous to Singapore, although last year at the Foo Yong Estate in Bukit Timah we had a local outbreak of malaria which resulted in 29 cases of

Column: 639

confirmed malaria, and this occurred in what is known as a controlled area; that is to say, although we had taken anti-malarial measures, yet there was a small outbreak of malaria. Therefore, all this while, we have to maintain a very vigilant attitude towards the mosquito problem. We have been reasonably successful for nearly 50 years in the control of malaria. But it is preferable, now that there is such a large mosquito nuisance in Singapore, that we should take one further step in establishing a centralised unit to control it.
